instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S3_EN_L: What is P3V3S3_EN_L? P3V3S3_EN_L is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is low. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi, I'm fairly new to logic board repair and schematic reading / electronics although I have been in the IT repair business for the last 20 years.

I'm trying to work out my first logic board repair and may well have got confused along the troubleshooting route. Could do with a helping hand!

These are my test results / notes:

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 14.8v SCHEMATIC SAYS 18.5v ??

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.35v SCHEMATIC SAYS 8.4V

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.29v SCHEMATIC SAYS 3.42v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.2v SCHEMATIC SAYS 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = -- SCHEMATIC SAYS 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = -- SCHEMATIC SAYS 5v

<RESISTOR>R7910</RESISTOR> Pin1 = 3.26v Pin2 = 3.11v 47k ohm tested ok
<CAPACITOR>C7911</CAPACITOR> Pin1 = 3.29v Pin2 = 3.17v
<CAPACITOR>C7910</CAPACITOR> Pin1 = 3.1v Pin2 = 0v
<TRANSISTOR>Q7903</TRANSISTOR> Pin1 = 0v Pin2=G Pin3 = 3.25v
<TRANSISTOR>Q7910</TRANSISTOR> Pin 4 = 3.29v Pin 3 = 3.11v Pin1,2,5,6 = 0v

There is no obvious water damage to the board and everything looks great and very clean.

Am I right in thinking the next step is to replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7910</TRANSISTOR>?

Of course, I could be mis-reading the schematic entirely and have the completely wrong end of the stick...

Cheers

Stewart

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Press power button or use power pads on the logic board.... This board does not power on by itself....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thank you, I thought they all turned on when power was given! Lesson learned. I do now get very fast fan spin and hot CPU. This leads me on to another problem but I will troubleshoot first before posting again.

I'm still not completely clear on where my logic failed. Everything looked like <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> should have turned on with the values I was testing? An explanation on where I went wrong on this would help me greatly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: In order to have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> you need <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>, this signal came from MCP and is sent only after press power button...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Fan spins fast because trackpad is not connected. Put it back together including battery and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks chaps. I will have to wait to test it once I get the rest of the machine sorted, also waiting for some donor boards to replace a couple of caps.

Am I right in thinking that my logic was nearly correct? The voltage at the gate was only slightly lower than the source but it was looking for 0v aka <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN_L</SIGNAL> so it could open? From my tests this seems the case.

Also is this expected / normal? <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 14.8v SCHEMATIC SAYS 18.5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You are looking for problems that are not there. Put this thing together and it will most likely be working.

PPDCIN will depend on what voltage your charger puts out. Apple is lazy and copy paste this stuff from other diagrams. Output voltage between 45/60/85W chargers are all different.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks for the info. I'm no't looking for problems just trying to learn the way these components work together. First time reading a schematic so it was a general question on <SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN_L</SIGNAL> and the MOSFET.
